title: If/Else Statements
description: Make decisions in your code with conditional logic

content.text: If/else statements let your program make decisions. They run different code based on whether a condition is True or False.

content.code:
age = 18

if age >= 18:
    print("You can vote!")
    print("You're an adult")

print("This always runs")
content.explanation: If the condition (age >= 18) is True, the indented code runs. Notice the colon : at the end of the if line!

content.text: Indentation matters in Python! Use 4 spaces (or Tab) to indent code inside if statements. All code at the same indentation level belongs together.
The if/else statement handles both cases:

content.explanation: If the condition is True, the if block runs. If it's False, the else block runs. Only one block will execute.

content.text: Comparison operators let you compare values:

content.code:
x = 10

print(x == 10)   # True (equal to)
print(x != 5)    # True (not equal to)
print(x > 5)     # True (greater than)
print(x < 20)    # True (less than)
print(x >= 10)   # True (greater than or equal)
print(x <= 15)   # True (less than or equal)
content.explanation: These operators return True or False. Use == to check equality (not =, which is for assignment!).

content.text: Common mistake: using = instead of ==. Remember: = assigns a value, == checks if values are equal!
The elif (else if) lets you check multiple conditions:

content.explanation: Python checks each condition in order. When it finds a True one, it runs that block and skips the rest.

content.code:
age = 25
has_license = True

# AND: both must be True
if age >= 18 and has_license:
    print("You can drive!")

# OR: at least one must be True
if age < 18 or age > 65:
    print("Special rate applies")

# NOT: reverses the condition
if not has_license:
    print("You need a license!")
content.explanation: 'and' requires both conditions to be True. 'or' requires at least one. 'not' flips True to False and vice versa.

content.text: You can nest if statements inside each other:

content.explanation: Each level of nesting adds 4 more spaces of indentation. Be careful not to nest too deeply - it gets hard to read!

content.text: Try to keep conditions simple and readable. If you have complex logic, break it into smaller pieces or use variables with descriptive names.
Truthy and falsy values in Python:

content.explanation: Empty values (0, empty string, empty list) are falsy. Non-empty values are truthy. This is useful for checking if something exists!
